headline.main: Making Your Home Look Like a Hotel Lobby

docs.abstract: Four Seasons hotels offer class in flower-arranging for guests who want to achieve hotel chic at home; photos (Currents column) (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Hotel chic has reached a fever pitch, with shoppers buying napery and drapery from hotels like the Ritz-Carlton and the W. Now there is another way to bring the aesthetic experience home: The Four Seasons is offering flower-arranging classes to guests who want to achieve that certain hotel-lobby insouciance-in-an-urn. In New York, Dallas, London, Paris, Toronto and Costa Rica, flower-lovers can learn at the elbow of the head florist (like James Pitman, above, in the London hotel), using indigenous flora and techniques. (Prices start at $35 per person; 800-332 3442 for information.) Once you've mastered the art, you can festoon your front hall with bouquets, load up a luggage cart and dress your spouse in a uniform and bell cap. ELLEN TIEN

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Deals: Priceline.com Acquires Active Hotels

docs.abstract: Priceline.com acquires Active Hotels of Britain for about $161 million in cash; graph (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Priceline.com, a seller of discount travel services on the Internet, said Tuesday that it had bought Active Hotels of Britain for about $161 million in cash as the company seeks to expand its online hotel-reservations business in Europe. The purchase was Priceline.com's largest and adds 8,000 hotel properties to the 11,000 that can be booked through its sites. The acquisition will add to fourth-quarter profit, said Priceline.com, based in Norwalk, Conn. Adding Active Hotels will help Priceline.com's chief executive, Jeffery H. Boyd, accelerate expansion into Europe, where he said the online travel business was growing faster than in the United States. Priceline.com said last month that bookings growth would slow to a gain of 44 percent to 48 percent in the second half of the year on lower increases for hotel rooms and rental cars. The company raised its fourth-quarter profit forecast excluding certain costs to 14 cents to 18 cents a share because of the acquisition, from its earlier forecast of 13 cents to 17 cents. Priceline.com had accumulated $386.2 million in cash and cash equivalents at the end of the second quarter. Part of the cash was obtained through two convertible debt offerings that generated $225 million in sales in the last 14 months. Shares of Priceline.com rose $1.62, to $21.22, yesterday.

headline.main: INDONESIA BOMBING KILLS AT LEAST 10 IN MIDDAY ATTACK

docs.abstract: Vehicle packed with explosives blows up in front of Marriott Hotel in Jakarta, killing at least ten people and wounding nearly 150 in hotel, restaurant and office building; photos; map; sites were frequented by Americans, but dead are all Indonesian except for Dutch banker Hans Winkelmolen; Indonesian court is about to announce verdicts in trials of accused Jemaah Islamiyah terrorists charged with Bali bombing that killed 202 people, many Australian; Prime Min John Howard links latest attack to group (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A sport utility vehicle packed with explosives blew up here in Indonesia's capital early Tuesday afternoon, killing at least 10, and as many as 15, people and wounding nearly 150 in a Marriott hotel, a large restaurant and an office building. It was the most devastating attack on Indonesian soil since the twin blasts in Bali last October. There were no immediate claims of responsibility, but because all three buildings were frequented by Americans, Indonesia's vice president, Hamzah Haz, said the attack appeared to have been aimed at American interests. [Page A10.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The same forces that are mauling the airlines are taking a heavy toll on the hotel business. ''We're seeing an unprecedented drop in demand,'' said Paul Whetsell, chief executive of Interstate Hotels and Resorts, the largest independent operator of hotels in the United States and Canada ''This is the worst I've seen in 30 years.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Who says the business world is full of nerdy overachievers? According to a recent survey, many business travelers have romance on their minds. For the survey, Hyatt Hotels asked business travelers how they would use a free hotel stay (a survey that just happened to coincide with a ''Free Nights'' promotion with American Express). And -- sorry, kids -- romantic vacations handily won out over family vacations, 36 percent to 27 percent. A mix of other vacation preferences -- exotic, adventure, solo and sightseeing -- split the remaining 37 percent. Some women may be holding out for something a bit more, well, long term. While 38 percent of single men went for the romantic getaway over the adventurous or the exotic, just 32 percent of women did. Where to? You must remember this: Sydney, at 39 percent, beat out Paris, at 24 percent, as the top romantic destination.

headline.main: Multifaceted Antiques Show Only Burnished by Adversity

docs.abstract: Roberta Smith reviews 48th Annual Winter Antiques Show, this year held at New York Hilton; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It's strange how making the best of things sometimes makes them better than usual. This feat has been achieved by the 48th Annual Winter Antiques Show with its unplanned relocation to the New York Hilton on the Avenue of the Americas at 53rd Street. The move was necessitated by last fall's mobilization of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street. The art and antiques fairs that call the armory home were thrown into disarray, and the cancellations included the prestigious International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show.

docs.abstract: Golfing for children at 14 Hyatt resorts noted (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: RESORT Hello, Young Duffers For parents who have seen Tiger Woods and are thinking of raising some Tiger cubs, Hyatt resorts can help. From now to Aug. 28, children ages 8 through 17 will be able to play a round of golf free each day, when accompanied by a paying adult, at 14 Hyatt resorts, including those at Dorado Beach in Puerto Rico; Grand Cayman; Hilton Head, S.C.; Maui, and Monterey, Calif. Information and reservations: (800) 446-5373. TOUR The Artist's Europe Smithsonian Study Tours is organizing two trips to Europe in September to explore regions that played major roles in the life of Pablo Picasso, in conjunction with the Picasso exhibit at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The young Picasso studied art in Barcelona, and from Sept. 5 to 14, a Smithsonian tour explores the city, stopping at the Picasso Museum, the Joan Miro Foundation and the Dali Museum. The price, with air fare, is $4,220 a person, double occupancy. From Sept. 17 to 29, the focus is on Renoir, Matisse and Picasso in a trip to the French Riviera. Stops include the Renoir and Matisse Museums, and the Matisse Chapel in Vence. Cost: $3,995 a person, double, with air fare. Information: (202) 357-4700. JOSEPH SIANO

docs.abstract: Exhibition of priceless diamonds will open at Harrah's Marina in Atlantic City on May 29 to celebrate Harrah's 60th year, or diamond anniversary; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ASKED how he felt about the exhibition of diamonds opening Thursday at Harrah's Marina, Harvey Rovinsky went through the words typically used to describe diamonds -- spectacular, unusual, amazing, unbelievable, rare -- and then paused, as if the words weren't enough. ''This show is a jeweler's dream,'' he said. ''These are some of the diamonds that people in the industry read about but never get a chance to see because they are privately owned and the owners almost never show them publicly. These are priceless, priceless pieces, the best of the best. I am not merely excited or thrilled. In awe is more like it.''

docs.abstract: South African prosecutor announces that he will not bring bribery charges against Solomon Kerzner, step that is likely to smooth way for gambling magnate to get license to operate casino in Atlantic City; Kerzner, chmn of Sun International Hotels, was accused of paying $600,000 bribe in 1986 to leader of South African puppet state, Transkei, to preserve his company's gambling monopoly in that country; Kerzner says he was victim of extortion; NJ Division of Gaming Enforcement says it will continue its own investigation into Kerzner's activities (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)
docs.lead_paragraph: A South African prosecutor announced yesterday that he would not bring bribery charges against Solomon Kerzner, a step that is likely to smooth the way for the gambling magnate to get a license to operate a casino in Atlantic City. Thomas N. Auriemma, deputy director of the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement, said his agency would continue its own investigation into Mr. Kerzner's activities. But the decision by a South African attorney general, Christo Nel, certainly helps Mr. Kerzner's cause.

headline.main: Harrah's Chosen as Operator Of Casino on Missouri River

docs.lead_paragraph: Harrah's Casino Hotels said yesterday that it had been chosen to build a $50 million, 1,550-passenger riverboat casino in North Kansas City, Mo., for operation on the Missouri River beginning in the second quarter of 1994. The ship will have about 900 slot machines and 55 gaming tables. Harrah's is a subsidiary of the Memphis-based Promus Companies, with interests in hotels and gaming. Promus is currently building two casino riverboats for a complex in downtown Joliet, Ill. It will begin construction in March of a riverboat for Vicksburg, Miss. And it is in exclusive negotiations with the City of Shreveport, La., for a riverboat casino there.
